item.title: Comp Semantics
item.description: S1: Rule-based computational semantics A1: Logic and lambda calculus S2: Distributional representations A2: Vector semantics S3: Distributed representations A3: Distributed Representations and Language Models S4: Contextualised word embeddings A4: LSTMs and BERT for Word Sense Disambiguation S5: Natural language inference A5: Natural Language Inference

item.title: Why Language Technology
item.description: As an enrolled postgraduate in Language Technology, I am really interested in so-called language. (Statistics can also be seen as a subject mainly composed of mathematical language and computer language.) Since I was young, I have had a unique talent that words can make me have “synaesthesia”: Each word conjures specific meanings and paints vivid images in my mind. To me, the world is a vast tapestry woven from words, grammar, sounds, and their endless combinations, each giving rise to different genres and expressions.

item.title: Why Timeless Song
item.description: This is my first post, and I am happy to start my blogging journey from here. During my bachelor’s study in Statistics, I begin to analyze data with renowned Iris dataset, which has plenty of features to be classified, summarized and visualized. As a polysemy, “iris” represents both iris flowers(“鸢尾&rdq
